cluster_classes.class_description: Social groups within ancient Egyptian society distinguished by status and burial practices, including both elite and non-elite non-royal populations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: High-status non-royal individuals... and common people in ancient Egypt, both described as social groups differentiated by status.

members.entity_description: High-status non-royal individuals in ancient Egyptian society who were granted elaborate tombs and burials.
Typical, non-elite members of ancient Egyptian society who, despite lacking the resources of the elite, were buried with care, respect, and items for use in the afterlife.

cluster_classes.class_description: Monumental tomb constructions in ancient Egypt, including pyramids and related burial complexes built to house the dead and support their afterlife.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: complex burial structures in ancient Egypt, including pyramids and monumental tombs such as the pyramids at Giza

members.entity_description: Complex, carefully constructed burial structures and chambers in ancient Egypt, including pyramids and other monumental tombs, built to house the deceased and their funerary goods and to ensure their passage into the afterlife.
Large monumental pyramid structures in ancient Egypt built as tombs to house and protect the deceased.
Famous pyramid complexes on the Giza Plateau built as monumental tombs for Egyptian rulers.

cluster_classes.class_description: Collective representations of ancient Egypt as a historical civilization, including its people, culture, and social structures.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: ancient Egyptian burial practices were a vital part of Egyptian culture and society... people of ancient Egypt... overall cultural system of ancient Egypt

members.entity_description: The people of ancient Egypt, responsible for developing and practicing the civilization's religious, social, and funerary customs, including mummification and tomb burials.
Historical civilization along the Nile River in northeastern Africa, known for its complex culture, elaborate burial practices, and monumental architecture.
The social, religious, artistic, and broader cultural traditions and practices that characterized the civilization of ancient Egypt.
The social structure, institutions, and communal life of ancient Egypt, including relationships between different social groups and classes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Supreme monarchs who governed ancient Egypt and for whom monumental tombs, such as pyramids, were constructed as burial places.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: monumental structures were built to house the pharaohs and other important individuals in the afterlife

members.entity_description: Rulers of ancient Egypt for whom monumental tombs like pyramids were constructed.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
args.justification: This class models social groups within ancient Egyptian society that are explicitly discussed in the context of burial practices, so it should be grouped with other classes covering ancient Egyptian society, rulers, and funerary culture.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
args.justification: This class covers monumental tomb structures (including pyramids at Giza) used in ancient Egyptian funerary practices and should share a Class_Group with other classes about ancient Egyptian society and burial-related culture.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
args.justification: This class already describes the overall ancient Egyptian civilization, including its culture and burial practices, so it should anchor the shared Class_Group that connects to social strata, rulers, and tomb structures.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
args.justification: This class covers pharaohs, the rulers for whom pyramids and other tomb structures were built; it belongs in the same Class_Group as the civilization, social strata, and tomb structure classes to reflect a coherent model of ancient Egyptian society and funerary culture.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
executed_decisions.justification: This class models social groups within ancient Egyptian society that are explicitly discussed in the context of burial practices, so it should be grouped with other classes covering ancient Egyptian society, rulers, and funerary culture.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
executed_decisions.justification: This class covers monumental tomb structures (including pyramids at Giza) used in ancient Egyptian funerary practices and should share a Class_Group with other classes about ancient Egyptian society and burial-related culture.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
executed_decisions.justification: This class already describes the overall ancient Egyptian civilization, including its culture and burial practices, so it should anchor the shared Class_Group that connects to social strata, rulers, and tomb structures.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
executed_decisions.justification: This class covers pharaohs, the rulers for whom pyramids and other tomb structures were built; it belongs in the same Class_Group as the civilization, social strata, and tomb structure classes to reflect a coherent model of ancient Egyptian society and funerary culture.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts referring to the dead person as the subject of ancient Egyptian burial, mummification, and afterlife practices, including both the individual and their preserved body.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Dead individual in ancient Egyptian burial practices... body of the dead person intended to be preserved and protected within the pyramid or tomb.

members.entity_description: Dead individual in ancient Egyptian burial practices, whose body is mummified, buried with goods and texts, and believed to journey through the afterlife.
The physical body of the dead person intended to be preserved and protected within the pyramid or tomb in ancient Egyptian burial practices.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated concepts involved in the Ancient Egyptian mummification practice, including the core embalming process, treatment of internal organs, desiccation using salt, and wrapping with linen bandages.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Egyptian body-preservation burial practice involving organ removal, drying out the body with salt, and wrapping it in linen bandages.

members.entity_description: Ancient Egyptian burial and embalming process of preserving a corpse to prevent decay and prepare it for the afterlife, involving body preservation through organ removal, desiccation, and wrapping.
Soft organs inside the body that were removed during mummification.
Use of salt to dry out a corpse as part of mummification.
Strips of linen cloth used to wrap the mummified body.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated beliefs, states, locations, and processes that constitute the ancient Egyptian conception of the afterlife, including the post-death realm, the soul’s journey, desired conditions, and the divine domain of the gods.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: All entities describe aspects of the ancient Egyptian afterlife: its realm, soul’s journey, goals like safe passage and eternal existence, and provisions for comfort and sustenance.

members.entity_description: The ancient Egyptian religious conception of the afterlife, encompassing the post-death realm, the journey of the soul, associated deities, and the rituals and practices intended to ensure safe passage and eternal life.
Divine domain in ancient Egyptian belief where the gods dwell and where the deceased sought to exist eternally after successfully navigating the afterlife.
Concept of pyramids functioning as an entry point from the living world to the afterlife.
State of ease and well-being intended for the deceased through burial items.
Provision of nourishment to the deceased through items buried with them.
Spiritual component of a person believed to be reunited with the body in the afterlife.
Spiritual voyage the deceased was believed to undertake after death.
Believed post-death existence for which Egyptians prepared the deceased with tombs and grave goods.
Desired successful journey of the deceased from death to the afterlife.

members.entity_name: eternal existence in the realm of the gods
members.entity_description: Ongoing, unending life of the deceased among the gods.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated practices and value systems in ancient Egypt concerning death, burial, and honoring the dead, encompassing both ritual procedures and underlying moral-religious attitudes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Both entities concern how ancient Egyptians buried and honored the dead, including rituals and cultural values of reverence.

members.entity_description: The complex customs, rituals, and methods used in ancient Egypt to prepare and inter the dead, involving priests, embalmers, and other specialists to ensure a proper transition to the afterlife and to honor the deceased.

members.entity_name: reverence for the deceased in ancient Egypt
members.entity_description: The cultural and moral value in ancient Egyptian society of showing honor, respect, and veneration to the dead, often expressed through funerary rites, memorial practices, and beliefs about the afterlife.

remarks: This class has been structurally split into more specific subclasses; consider deprecating or hiding it from primary use once downstream references are updated.

cluster_classes.class_description: Roles comprising the professional participants in ancient Egyptian burial practices, including religious officiants, body preparers, and other specialized contributors.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The process of burial...required the expertise of priests, embalmers, and other skilled individuals.

members.entity_description: Religious specialists involved in performing and overseeing ancient Egyptian burial rituals.
Specialists responsible for preparing and preserving bodies during ancient Egyptian burials.
Additional unnamed specialists contributing expertise to the ancient Egyptian burial process.

splits.name: Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices
splits.description: The complex customs, rituals, and methods used in ancient Egypt to prepare and inter the dead, including preparation of the body, tomb arrangements, and associated rites to ensure a proper transition to the afterlife.

splits.name: Reverence for the Deceased in Ancient Egypt
splits.description: The cultural and moral value in ancient Egyptian society of showing honor, respect, and veneration to the dead, expressed through funerary rites, memorial practices, and beliefs about the afterlife.

args.justification: ClsC_cbdd742c mixes a concrete process ('ancient Egyptian burial practices') with an abstract moral value ('reverence for the deceased'); splitting yields cleaner, single-focus classes for practices vs values.

args.new_description: Concepts referring to the dead individual as the subject of ancient Egyptian burial, mummification, and afterlife practices, including both the person and their preserved body.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Renaming clarifies that this class covers the deceased as the focal subject of funerary treatment, and assigning a shared Class_Group connects it to the broader ancient Egyptian funerary schema.

args.new_description: Interrelated practices involved in ancient Egyptian mummification, including the embalming process, treatment and removal of internal organs, desiccation using salts, and wrapping with linen bandages.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Updated name and description emphasize practical, ritual actions and aligning the Class_Group situates mummification within the overall funerary religion and culture domain.

args.new_name: Ancient Egyptian Afterlife Beliefs and Concepts
args.new_description: Beliefs, states, locations, and processes that constitute the ancient Egyptian conception of the afterlife, including the post-death realm, the soul's journey, desired conditions such as comfort and sustenance, and eternal existence among the gods.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Minor renaming and shared Class_Group clarify that this class focuses on the belief and conceptual side of the same funerary religious system as the other classes.

args.new_description: Former umbrella class for both burial practices and reverence values in ancient Egyptian funerary culture; its members have been split into more specific classes.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.remark: This class has been structurally split into more specific subclasses; consider deprecating or hiding it from primary use once downstream references are updated.
args.justification: After splitting ClsC_cbdd742c into focused practice and value classes, updating its metadata and Class_Group clarifies its superseded/container status for maintainers.

args.new_description: The complex customs, rituals, and methods used in ancient Egypt to prepare and inter the dead, encompassing body preparation, tomb arrangements, offerings, and associated rites to ensure a proper transition to the afterlife.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Assigning an explicit Class_Group and refining the name/description position this split-out class as the general umbrella for burial procedures within the funerary system.

args.new_name: Reverence for the Deceased in Ancient Egypt
args.new_description: The cultural and moral value in ancient Egyptian society of honoring, respecting, and venerating the dead, expressed through funerary rites, memorialization, and beliefs about the afterlife.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Clarifying this split-out class as a cultural value and assigning the shared Class_Group highlights its role as the normative/ideological dimension of the funerary system.

args.new_description: Occupational roles comprising the professional participants in ancient Egyptian burial practices, including priests, embalmers, and other specialized contributors involved in funerary rituals and body preparation.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Assigning the shared Class_Group and slightly expanding the description clearly link these roles to the common funerary religion and culture context.

executed_decisions.justification: ClsC_cbdd742c mixes a concrete process ('ancient Egyptian burial practices') with an abstract moral value ('reverence for the deceased'); splitting yields cleaner, single-focus classes for practices vs values.

executed_decisions.new_description: Concepts referring to the dead individual as the subject of ancient Egyptian burial, mummification, and afterlife practices, including both the person and their preserved body.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
executed_decisions.justification: Renaming clarifies that this class covers the deceased as the focal subject of funerary treatment, and assigning a shared Class_Group connects it to the broader ancient Egyptian funerary schema.

executed_decisions.new_description: Interrelated practices involved in ancient Egyptian mummification, including the embalming process, treatment and removal of internal organs, desiccation using salts, and wrapping with linen bandages.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
executed_decisions.justification: Updated name and description emphasize practical, ritual actions and aligning the Class_Group situates mummification within the overall funerary religion and culture domain.

executed_decisions.new_name: Ancient Egyptian Afterlife Beliefs and Concepts
executed_decisions.new_description: Beliefs, states, locations, and processes that constitute the ancient Egyptian conception of the afterlife, including the post-death realm, the soul's journey, desired conditions such as comfort and sustenance, and eternal existence among the gods.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
executed_decisions.justification: Minor renaming and shared Class_Group clarify that this class focuses on the belief and conceptual side of the same funerary religious system as the other classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Former umbrella class for both burial practices and reverence values in ancient Egyptian funerary culture; its members have been split into more specific classes.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
executed_decisions.remark: This class has been structurally split into more specific subclasses; consider deprecating or hiding it from primary use once downstream references are updated.
executed_decisions.justification: After splitting ClsC_cbdd742c into focused practice and value classes, updating its metadata and Class_Group clarifies its superseded/container status for maintainers.

executed_decisions.new_description: The complex customs, rituals, and methods used in ancient Egypt to prepare and inter the dead, encompassing body preparation, tomb arrangements, offerings, and associated rites to ensure a proper transition to the afterlife.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
executed_decisions.justification: Assigning an explicit Class_Group and refining the name/description position this split-out class as the general umbrella for burial procedures within the funerary system.

executed_decisions.new_name: Reverence for the Deceased in Ancient Egypt
executed_decisions.new_description: The cultural and moral value in ancient Egyptian society of honoring, respecting, and venerating the dead, expressed through funerary rites, memorialization, and beliefs about the afterlife.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
executed_decisions.justification: Clarifying this split-out class as a cultural value and assigning the shared Class_Group highlights its role as the normative/ideological dimension of the funerary system.

executed_decisions.new_description: Occupational roles comprising the professional participants in ancient Egyptian burial practices, including priests, embalmers, and other specialized contributors involved in funerary rituals and body preparation.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
executed_decisions.justification: Assigning the shared Class_Group and slightly expanding the description clearly link these roles to the common funerary religion and culture context.

cluster_classes.class_description: Human agents who participate in or organize funerary activities, including relatives of the deceased and hired mourning specialists.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The deceased's family would often hire professional mourners to lead the funeral procession and perform rituals.

members.entity_description: Relatives of the deceased person who arrange funerary activities and hire mourners.
Hired specialists who publicly mourn, lead funeral processions, and perform funerary rituals.

cluster_classes.class_description: Ceremonial actions conducted as part of funerals, including the movement of the deceased and mourners and associated ritual performances.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Professional mourners... lead the funeral procession and perform rituals to honor the deceased.

members.entity_description: The ceremonial movement of mourners and the deceased's remains during the funeral.
Ritual actions performed to honor the deceased as part of burial practices.

args.new_description: Human agents who participate in or organize funerary activities, including relatives of the deceased, professional mourners, and other ritual specialists.
args.justification: This class is correctly scoped to human agents involved in funerary contexts and should remain distinct from ritual processes; updating the label/description for clarity and assigning a shared funerary-focused Class_Group connects it appropriately to related classes without merging different concepts.

args.new_description: Ceremonial processes conducted as part of funerals, including funeral processions and associated ritual actions performed to honor the deceased.
args.justification: This class cleanly captures funerary processes rather than social roles; refining the label/description and placing it in the same Funerary Roles and Ritual Practices Class_Group as the participants class preserves the role–process distinction while structurally linking related funerary concepts.

executed_decisions.new_description: Human agents who participate in or organize funerary activities, including relatives of the deceased, professional mourners, and other ritual specialists.
executed_decisions.justification: This class is correctly scoped to human agents involved in funerary contexts and should remain distinct from ritual processes; updating the label/description for clarity and assigning a shared funerary-focused Class_Group connects it appropriately to related classes without merging different concepts.

executed_decisions.new_description: Ceremonial processes conducted as part of funerals, including funeral processions and associated ritual actions performed to honor the deceased.
executed_decisions.justification: This class cleanly captures funerary processes rather than social roles; refining the label/description and placing it in the same Funerary Roles and Ritual Practices Class_Group as the participants class preserves the role–process distinction while structurally linking related funerary concepts.

cluster_classes.class_description: Objects intentionally buried with the deceased for use or comfort in the afterlife, including both general assemblages of items and specific implements such as tools.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: items buried with the dead for use in the afterlife, such as food, tools, and personal belongings

members.entity_description: Collections of the deceased's personal belongings and other items, such as food, tools, jewelry, and clothing, placed in the tomb or grave for use and comfort in the afterlife.
Implements buried with the deceased to be used in the afterlife.

cluster_classes.class_description: Grave goods intentionally buried with the deceased, including food, clothing, and jewelry meant for use or benefit in the afterlife.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Items could include food, clothing, jewelry, and other personal belongings buried with the deceased.

members.entity_description: Edible items placed in tombs or graves as provisions for the deceased in the afterlife.
Garments buried with the deceased to be used in the afterlife.
Jewelry placed in the tomb with the deceased as grave goods for the afterlife.

args.new_description: Objects and assemblages intentionally buried with the deceased—such as food, tools, clothing, jewelry, and other personal belongings—intended for use, provision, or comfort in the afterlife.
args.justification: Both classes describe the same concept of objects buried with the dead for use or benefit in the afterlife (grave goods, food, clothing, jewelry, tools) and differ only in emphasis and type_hint, so they should be unified into a single funerary goods class.
The merged class clearly belongs to the domain of objects associated with burials and the afterlife, so assigning a mortuary-focused Class_Group connects it appropriately within the schema.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes describe the same concept of objects buried with the dead for use or benefit in the afterlife (grave goods, food, clothing, jewelry, tools) and differ only in emphasis and type_hint, so they should be unified into a single funerary goods class.
The merged class clearly belongs to the domain of objects associated with burials and the afterlife, so assigning a mortuary-focused Class_Group connects it appropriately within the schema.

cluster_classes.class_description: Religious written works placed in ancient Egyptian burials, such as the Book of the Dead, intended to guide and protect the deceased in the afterlife.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: religious texts and prayers placed in tombs to aid the deceased in navigating the afterlife

members.entity_description: Ancient Egyptian funerary text consisting of a collection of spells and prayers, often written on papyrus scrolls and placed in tombs to aid the deceased in navigating the afterlife.

members.entity_name: religious texts in ancient Egyptian burials
members.entity_description: Sacred written works placed in ancient Egyptian tombs or burial chambers to guide and aid the deceased in the afterlife.

cluster_classes.class_description: Protective or magical objects placed in ancient Egyptian burials to aid and protect the deceased in the afterlife.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Protective ritual objects included in burials for afterlife protection.

members.entity_description: Protective or magical objects placed in ancient Egyptian burials to aid and protect the deceased in the afterlife.

cluster_classes.class_description: Rooms or enclosed spaces designed to house mummified bodies along with religious texts, amulets, and other provisions for the journey to the afterlife in ancient Egyptian mortuary contexts.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Room or space in which the mummified deceased, texts, and amulets were placed.

members.entity_description: Room or space in which the mummified deceased, texts, and amulets were placed.

cluster_classes.class_description: Papyrus-based scrolls or sheets used as writing supports, particularly for inscribing religious or funerary texts such as the Book of the Dead.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The Book of the Dead was often inscribed on papyrus scrolls and placed in the tomb.

members.entity_description: Papyrus-based writing material used to inscribe the Book of the Dead.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
args.justification: This class describes funerary religious texts used in ancient Egyptian burials, aligning with the shared domain of Egyptian funerary practice alongside amulets, burial chambers, and papyrus manuscripts.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
args.justification: This class covers amulets placed in tombs for afterlife protection, clearly part of the same ancient Egyptian funerary and burial practice domain as the other classes in the cluster.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
args.justification: This class represents burial chambers that house mummies along with texts and amulets, making it part of the same overarching domain of ancient Egyptian funerary practices and burials.

args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
args.justification: Papyrus manuscripts here are specifically used as supports for funerary texts like the Book of the Dead in tombs, so they belong in the same class group focused on ancient Egyptian funerary practices and burial contexts.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
executed_decisions.justification: This class describes funerary religious texts used in ancient Egyptian burials, aligning with the shared domain of Egyptian funerary practice alongside amulets, burial chambers, and papyrus manuscripts.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
executed_decisions.justification: This class covers amulets placed in tombs for afterlife protection, clearly part of the same ancient Egyptian funerary and burial practice domain as the other classes in the cluster.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
executed_decisions.justification: This class represents burial chambers that house mummies along with texts and amulets, making it part of the same overarching domain of ancient Egyptian funerary practices and burials.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
executed_decisions.justification: Papyrus manuscripts here are specifically used as supports for funerary texts like the Book of the Dead in tombs, so they belong in the same class group focused on ancient Egyptian funerary practices and burial contexts.
